data.prayer: Father, we pray the believers are good spiritual stewards of their everyday relationships in Ambala, Haryana, India.

data.location_label: Photo from the county of Ambala, Haryana, India

data.prayer: Father, like with the Ethiopian Eunuch, set up a meeting today between a faithful believer in Ambala, Haryana, India and a person seeking to understand the truth.
data.verse: The eunuch asked Philip, “Tell me, please, who is the prophet talking about, himself or someone else?” Then Philip began with that very passage of Scripture and told him the good news about Jesus.

data.prayer: Father, for all those you call to look after your flock from the 12,412 believers in Ambala, please, make them passionate about hearing your Word.
data.verse: Therefore, you shepherds, hear the word of the LORD.

data.prayer: Father, see the suffering of your people in the county of Ambala. Deliver all those who have not forgotten your Word.
data.verse: Look on my suffering and deliver me, for I have not forgotten your law.

data.prayer: Lord, I thank you that you will bring health and a cure to the Rajput Jatu people. Reveal to them abundance of peace and truth.
Father, you desire to blot out the sins of the people of Ambala, Haryana, India. You said, if they turn to you, you will dissolve their sins like mist.
data.verse: I have blotted out, as a thick cloud, your transgressions, and, as a cloud, your sins. Return to me, for I have redeemed you.

data.prayer: Spirit, make the church in Ambala, Haryana, India humble and willing to hear the sometimes hard voices of prophets bringing the light of truth on them.
data.verse: So have I become your enemy by telling you the truth?

data.prayer: Father, convict the 12,412 believers in Ambala to be holy and righteous. Inspire them to gather in small groups for accountability and spiritual growth.

location.name: Ambala
location.people_groups_list: Jat Makiwal, Jat Ghatwal (Hindu traditions), Khati (Muslim traditions), Gawaria, Bhat (Hindu traditions)
location.people_groups_list_w_pop: Jat Makiwal (19,000), Jat Ghatwal (Hindu traditions) (192,000), Khati (Muslim traditions) (11,000), Gawaria (88,000), Bhat (Hindu traditions) (1,371,000)
